DOC.HEAD: Security Lapses Plague Beaver Valley Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: The director of an anti-nuclear power group says he's alarmed the Beaver Valley nuclear plant did not get fined for lapses that included security officers napping on the job. ``If you have this many lapses in a good program, it's scary to think what a bad program is like,'' said Ken Bossong, director of the Critical Mass Energy Project, which is affiliated with the consumer group Public Citizen. ``The absence of any fines or other reprimands shows lax oversight'' by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, he said. A plant security officer tampered with a safety-related device and others slept on duty, The Pittsburgh Press reported Thursday. The newspaper also said a security supervisor at the plant in Shippingport, about 25 miles from Pittsburgh, placed an unloaded pistol in his mouth and pulled the trigger in January 1988. And in October, two guards each allowed a person to enter the plant without required authorization. The newspaper said its report was based on a review of NRC records and interviews with officials at the NRC and Duquesne Light Co., the operator of the two-reactor complex. Duquesne Light spokesman Kenneth Service said the incidents drew strong disciplinary action, including firings and suspensions. No fines were imposed by the NRC. ``Throughout this period we've had a high level of security and continue to have a high level of security,'' Service said. ``None of these individual items in any way degraded the level of security or safety at the plant.'' The NRC's past three performance assessments, covering 1986 through August 1989, gave Duquesne Light the highest of three possible ratings for security.
